A fix for one version is often not be applicable for other code versions, such fixes require additional testing, etc. By allowing to select several fix versions we are forced to implement additional mechanisms and processes to ensure that we fix and test all versions.

JIRA's HTML update emails make use of columns.  The left-hand column (Issue, key, issue type, etc.) takes up about 40% of the screen.  The right-hand column is the body, and takes up about 60% of the screen.  the fields (reporter type, new comment, etc.) often have fixed indent sizes.

The result of that formatting is that the actual content of the alert is only one character wide.  It creates a gigantic vertical scroll, reading a long, vertical sentence.

Workaround: use plain text emails.  use a different email client.

Still, it would be nice if I could view my emails on my iPhone.
fields.summary: improve HTML email readability in mobile devices like iPhone - make column sizes relative

fields.description:
We have a project which have 15 differents components.  In the administration tab of this project we keep all the versions of each components.  This means we have a lot of versions (~150 versions) for this project (many versions of each components) .  When we try to manage those versions (add, delete, release or reorder them)  it takes too much time.  It can take more than 3 minutes for the request to complete when creating a new version.

I don't know what is causing those delay but it seems to be the only place where Jira is so slow, the other pages are responding relativly quickly and the server doesn't seems to be overcharged since the load average stay low.
fields.summary: Take too much time to create a version in the administration section

fields.description:
It could be a great improvement to add condition on specific event.

Example #1: If Resolved Notification is sent, don't send Updated Notification (because a Resolved Event include that the Issue is updated).
Example #2: Don't send a Commented or Updated Notification, if the issues Resolved.


Another great improvement should be to be able to customize the e-mail (Subject & Description) that is sent as a Notification.

Example #1: Add the status in the subject of the e-mail: [JIRA] Resolved: (TEST-679) Summary, Statuts, etc.
Example #2: Be able to customize the e-mail or add custom field by linking a notification to a Screen.

Thanks

Benoit Filiatreault
Ubisoft
fields.summary: Conditional Events + customizable E-mail Notificaiton [REQUESTID:260028]

Probably you can put the "Add Watchers" widget along with the comment form so that if I want to add a new person, I can do that from there itself.

If one needs to be able to restart each individual JIRA webapp without affecting any other webapp (JIRA or any other webapp), a single JIRA webapp should be configured per JVM (and therefore per Tomcat instance).

If restarting multiple webapps at the same time is not an issue, then running multiple webapps in the same Tomcat (and therefore JVM) instance is fine.

We should mention these points in the requirements section of JIRA documentation.

The reloading of webapps in Tomcat is very tricky to get working and does not work with JIRA, leading to OutOfMemoryErrors after a few reloads - JRA-15489.
fields.summary: Document that for maximum flexibility one should run one webvapp per JVM

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce the problem:

# Create an issue in Project A and add an attachment
# Bulk Move that issue to Project B, but wait before confirming the Bulk Move.
# In a second browser, log in with the same user, Bulk Move the same issue to Project B, and confirm the operation. You can see that the issue is moved, it got assigned a new issue id in the new project, and the attachment is moved to the correct path.
# Confirm the bulk move in the first browser. You get an error saying {noformat}Error
The issue you are trying to view does not exist.{noformat}. The logs will report {noformat}Bulk edit bean unexpectedly null. Perhaps session was lost (e.g. when URL used is different to base URL in General Configuration)?{noformat}
# The second bulk move partially succeeds. A new issue id is given in the new project, and the change history is reflected accordingly. However, the file attachment is lost.

It is likely that this situation would be reproducible by clicking the back button on the browser while bulk moving, if there were many issues on the bulk move.

The first bulk move operation did move the attachment from the old project to the new one. The second bulk move still tries to move the attachment from the old location, and fails.

At the very least, the {{BulkMoveOperation.moveAttachments}} function should check whether the {{renameTo}} function succeeds or fails, and log an error message if failure. Ideally, this situation would be prevented all together, and either the move of that issue would fail, or the attachment would be moved successfully.
fields.summary: Attachment lost with parallel bulk moves

fields.description:
If a web request takes longer than some threshold (say 30 secs) then a Thread Sump should be taken.

h2. The Support Use Case

Often in support, we are left wondering what is going on during "performance" problems.  

We often ask the customer to generate a thread dump so we can look inside the state of the system.

However often it too late.  The system may have gone back to a steady state, and the chance of a customer generated a stack trace at just the right time can be slim.

h2. Design Considerations

The actual threshold should be configurable.  Customers will want it at different levels and perhaps not at all.  Perhaps via a Java system property so it can be turned on and off at runtime via code.  Or a log4j switch with custom formatter.

The number of thread dumps generated should be governed within a time frame (say no more than 5 per minute).  

If a system is runing slow, then chances are all requests will take longer than the threshold and hence too many thread dumps may be generated with some governing.

The thread dump should be output to the logs in such as way as it can easily be extracted into a thread dump tool.

Perhaps a specific thread dump file should be generated so each event can be more easily identified.

On a slow system where lots of thread dumps happen, the size of the logs will expand.  perhaps this is unavoidable since we want the valuable support information.

ps.  KUDOS goes to Brenden Bain for thinking of this idea.  I reckon its  corker!
fields.summary: If a web request takes to long, a thread dump should be generated

fields.description:
When creating Event Type Ids for Custom Issues, JIRA starts at 10000.

When creating a custom Listener to handle these events you need to deal with both Event Type Ids and Template Ids.

Being able to have the Template Id equal the Event Type Id for a given Event would allow for very clean code.

If you go to email-template-id-mappings.xml, you find the following:
{noformat}
    <!--
         This is not mapped to an event type, these are the templates that are used when generating
         the mails sent out for filter subscriptions. The id has changed from 14 to 10000 in JIRA 3.8.
    -->
    <templatemapping id="10000">
        <name>Filter Subscription</name>
        <template>filtersubscription.vm</template>
        <templatetype>filtersubscription</templatetype>
    </templatemapping>
{noformat}

Atlassian has already reserved templatemapping id 10000 for Filter Subscription.

Therefore, you are forced to start the templatemapping ids for your custom events at 10001. This forces you to do one of two things:
# Define an extra set of static values which are equal to Issue Type Id + 1 as your Template Type Ids
# Use Issue Type Id + 1 whenever you reference a Template Type Id.

Neither is a nice choice. 

Please consider changing the Template Id for Filter Subscription in the future, so that you have a clean address space for templatemapping ids which matches up with Event Type Ids.

Please consider ease of programming when making choices for constant values such as this one.
fields.summary: Align Event Type Ids and Template IDs - change Filter Subscription Template IDs

fields.description:
The feature could consist on having an option at the reporting side of project page which we would call *'my reports'* or *'my saved reports'*. At which I can select a saved report invocation in which we have stored:
- the report plugin invoked
- all the parameters set at that time (if some of the parameters is a date, and value = today's date, this is not stored but generated on each invocation)
- the name of this report invocation

So this *'my reports'* would be populated when we run a standard report. For instance, I run a time tracking report defining a time period with my project filter, etc. Below all plugin parameters, I have a textbox whose label says 'save this in my reports', which gets activated by setting the name on the textbox of course.
If so, the info is persisted and then listed after on the myreports list.

This is the kind of feat which could bring JIRA from wonderful to unbeatable.
fields.summary: Being able to save a report invocation (with parameters set) so they can be named and thereby invoked afterwards in one-click

fields.description:
Guys,

for non HSQL, {{entityengine.xml}} currently lists for the datasource (example)
{noformat}
    <datasource name="defaultDS" field-type-name="mysql"
      helper-class="org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericHelperDAO"
      check-on-start="true"
      use-foreign-keys="false"
      use-foreign-key-indices="false"
      check-fks-on-start="false"
      check-fk-indices-on-start="false"
      add-missing-on-start="true"
      check-indices-on-start="true">
        <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="java:/DefaultDS"/>
<!-- Orion format: <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="jdbc/JiraDS"/> -->
<!-- JBoss format: <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="java:/DefaultDS"/> -->
<!-- Weblogic format: <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="JiraDS"/> -->
{noformat}

If you configure for non-HSQL and follow the [jboss4|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/servers/jboss4.html] docs, it advises, correctly, to configure the jndi-name as *java:/JiraDS*, yet in the XML flat file itself, it says
{quote}<!-- JBoss format: <jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name="default" jndi-name="java:/DefaultDS"/> -->{quote}
Which is only valid if you use HSQL; HSQL is pre-configured at DefaultDS in the JNDI tree, but if you use non-HSQL, the docs direct you to configure a JNDI element at "java:/JiraDS".

Jboss tries to acquire the JDBC driver via JNDI at JiraDS (as configured in {{server/default/deploy/jira-ds.xml}}), but fails because OfBiz has already registered it to DefaultDS

This is an expensive bug to debug from a support perspective, since we don't strictly support Jboss.

Please see [JSP-26808|https://support.atlassian.com/browse/JSP-26808] for backstory.

Cheers
fields.summary: jndi-jdbc jndi-server-name directions in entityengine.xml is not correct for jboss and external database

fields.description:
It's easiest to explain this with an example.

I have a custom User field called Tester.  If the filter used in the 2D Filter Statistics portlet contains issues with no value for Tester, and we use Tester as the X-axis field, the portlet displays a column for "None".

Since it's (currently ;-) ) impossible to filter on empty values, the "None" header and non-zero rows are not hyperlinked.  However, the totals row *is* hyperlinked and it displays all issues.  The "None" total should not be a link.

The same thing happens with the Totals column if you make Tester the X-axis field.
fields.summary: Invalid totals links in 2D Filter Statistics portlet

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15431].
  {panel}

h3. The Problem

Permissions on the support projects in https://support.atlassian.com (SAC) are configured to allow all actions to Atlassian and to the reporter (the customer), and no access to anyone else. That is customers can only see and do stuff on their own cases.

(Actually we also allow access to all members of the CC multi-user custom field, so that we can add in work colleagues of the reporter.)

This also, of course, applies to [comments added to an issue via email|http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/issue_creation_email.html]. An email containing an issue key will be added as a comment on the issue, but only if the email address matches a user who is the reporter of the issue or Atlassian (or a member of the CC field).

However with this configuration, the following use case is a problem:
# Customer gets an email notification from one of their cases in [SAC|https://support.atlassian.com]. For example, the support engineer has responded to their case.
# The customer's email client is configured so that their email address is set to a different one to their email address in SAC, often an email alias. For example, if their account in SAC has email address fsmith@example.com, the email address in their email client might be fred.smith@example.com.
# The customer replies to the email.
# SAC receives the email and:
## checks to see if there is a user with that email address
## _creates a user if there isn't one_
## then rejects the reply because the user does not have access to the issue. (The user for fsmith@example.com may have been the reporter, but the user for fred.smith@example.com does not have permission.)
## forwards it to the mail handler forward address for a human to deal with the error
# One of our triage engineers deals with the error by manually adding the email content as a comment to the email, adds any attachments in the email, and uses his judgement to decide whether to add the "other" user (i.e. fred.smith@example.com) to the CC field for that issue. *

A variation of this is that the customer receives the email notification, hasn't got time to respond as they are about to go home, so forwards it to their home email account, then responds to it when they get home. Same result.

We get on average 10 of these per day on SAC.

The problem has the following impact:
- The triage engineer has to manually deal with them.
- We end up with multiple accounts for the same customer. In some cases, this leads to the customer reporting some issues as one user, and some as the other, then complaining that they can't see all their issues when they log in.
- The combination of dealing with the above two points takes the triage engineer on average 1 hour per day.
- We end up with a whole bunch of extra accounts we don't need. If/when we move to a single user base behind SAC, JAC and all our other systems, we (presumably) won't be able to account new accounts from emails anyway, so it is a problem we will have to deal with eventually anyway.

\* If we do add the other user to the CC field (and it is not always the case that we do), we can then re-send the email to JIRA, and the email (and its attachments) will be added to the issue. However the email we need to resend is actually an attachment to the email that is sent to the forward mail box, and the only email client that we are aware of that will allow us to re-send an email attached to another email is ... [mutt|http://www.mutt.org]. Sigh.

h3. The Proposed Solution

1. Add an extra parameter to all the comment email handlers called something like _anonymouscomments_. When _anonymouscomments=true_, if there is not a user in JIRA matching the email address, add the comment anonymously to the issue, with the first line of the comment displaying the email address and, if present, the full name pulled from the email.

Thus, the email is added to the issue as the customer would have wanted. No new user is created in JIRA, so no one who shouldn't have access to JIRA or the issue gets access. The email notification resulting from the new comment is sent out to the correct users.

However, given that the whole world can now add comments to issues in JIRA, this opens the door to spam and denial of service attacks. (Denial of service attacks because unlimited comments added to an issue eventually results in OutOfMemoryErrors.) In order to mitigate these:

2. For the specific case of _anonymouscomments=true_ and there not being a JIRA user with the email address (i.e. when we are about to make an anonymous comment), rather than just matching against issue key in the email subject, also match the remainder of the email subject against the issue summary. If they don't match, don't add a comment and do the normal email error handling/forwarding.

This covers off the case where a malicious somebody with no access to the JIRA instance is just auto-generating issue keys and hammering the JIRA instance with emails with those keys.

3. Add another parameter to all the comment email handlers called something like _maxcomments_. Example usage: _maxcomments=1000_. The mail handler will not add a comment to an issue if there are already <maxcomments> comments on the issue. The JIRA admin could set this to a value higher than you would ever get in normal usage, but less than would start to cause OutOfMemoryErrors or related problems.

*Note:* In discussions about this problem and proposed solution, some people initially suggested that we should also send an email to the user saying that that their email address is different to the one in SAC. I don't think we should do this, as it is our experience of when we have done this when manually handling these problem emails, that this confuses and annoys some users. They don't understand or (legitimately, I feel) don't care. They just want it to work.

We have the same problem on one of our internal Atlassian JIRA instances, and I'm sure that there would be customers who have the same problem and would benefit from the solution.
fields.summary: Allow anonymous comments from email when no matching user

fields.description:
If you try to delete a JIRA user who is the assignee or reporter of an issue, then you will not be allowed.
However, you can currently delete users that are referred to in Custom Fields.
When this happens, JIRA remembers the username that the field was set to, but when you view the issue, it is not displayed, and a Warning message will appear in the logs like:
{noformat}
WARN [issue.customfields.impl.AbstractSingleFieldType] Issue RAT-10 has an invalid value 'fred' stored in the field 'Dude'. User 'fred' was not found in the system.
{noformat}
This should be handled better, by one of the following:
1. JIRA allows custom fields to veto the user delete, just like reporter and assignee fields
2. If the user is deleted, the User Custom field can still display the old username, and not log warnings.
3. if the user is deleted, the user Custom field acts as though the username was deleted from its value, and it doesn't log warnings.
Note that 3. is probably the easiest to achieve, and closest to the current behaviour.
fields.summary: The User Custom Field should handle users being deleted.

fields.description:
I am using SOAPpy (a python SOAP module) to add new versions to a jira project.  I have a problem where the release date I specify for the new version is not the one that ends up being set for the new version.  The day is one less than what I specify.  For example, if I specify a release date of 2008-12-25, the new version will have a release date of 2008-12-24.  Here is an example of the python code:
{code}
soap = SOAPpy.WSDL.Proxy(soapProxyURL)
auth = soap.login(JIRA_USER, JIRA_PASS)
versionInfo = {'name' : versionName,
                         'releaseDate' : SOAPpy.dateTimeType(2008, 12, 25, 0, 0, 0, 3, 360, -1)}
soap.addVersion(auth, projectKey, versionInfo)
{code}

More telling is when I debug the data that is actually being sent and returned from the server.  Here is the SOAP package that is being sent (notice the release date is the 25th):
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<SOAP-ENV:Envelope
  SOAP-ENV:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"
  xmlns:SOAP-ENC="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/"
  xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/1999/XMLSchema-instance"
  xmlns:SOAP-ENV="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/"
  xmlns:xsd3="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
  xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/1999/XMLSchema"
>
<SOAP-ENV:Body>
<ns1:addVersion xmlns:ns1="http://jiradev.anim.com:8080/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2" SOAP-ENC:root="1">
<v1 xsi:type="xsd:string">5xI725381q</v1>
<v2 xsi:type="xsd:string">INFRA</v2>
<v3>
<releaseDate xsi:type="xsd3:dateTime">2008-12-25T00:00:00Z</releaseDate>
<name xsi:type="xsd:string">2008.05</name>
</v3>
</ns1:addVersion>
</SOAP-ENV:Body>
</SOAP-ENV:Envelope>

Here is the data being sent in the response from the server (notice how the release date is not the 24th):
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?><soapenv:Envelope xmlns:soapenv="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/envelope/" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/1999/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/1999/XMLSchema-instance"><soapenv:Body><ns1:addVersionResponse soapenv:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xmlns:ns1="http://jiradev.anim.com:8080/rpc/soap/jirasoapservice-v2"><addVersionReturn href="#id0"/></ns1:addVersionResponse><multiRef id="id0" soapenc:root="0" soapenv:encodingStyle="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xsi:type="ns2:RemoteVersion" xmlns:soapenc="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/soap/encoding/" xmlns:ns2="http://beans.soap.rpc.jira.atlassian.com"><archived xsi:type="ns3:boolean" xmlns:ns3="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">false</archived><id xsi:type="ns4:string" xmlns:ns4="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">10506</id><name xsi:type="ns5:string" xmlns:ns5="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">2008.05</name><releaseDate xsi:type="ns6:dateTime" xmlns:ns6="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">2008-12-24T08:00:00.000Z</releaseDate><released xsi:type="ns7:boolean" xmlns:ns7="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">false</released><sequence xsi:type="ns8:long" xmlns:ns8="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema">8</sequence></multiRef></soapenv:Body></soapenv:Envelope>

I don't believe this has anything to do with the SOAPpy python module since it is eventually creating a SOAP package with the correct date and sending it across the network.  Is this a bug in Jira or am I formatting the date incorrectly?
fields.summary: SOAP: addVersion sets the incorrect date

fields.description:
We have received a stack trace from a customer where, during their performance testing, [DateFormat's parse function|http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/text/DateFormat.html#parse(java.lang.String)] has thrown a Runtime Exception, [java.lang.NumberFormatException|http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/lang/NumberFormatException.html]:

{noformat}
java.lang.NumberFormatException: multiple points
        at sun.misc.FloatingDecimal.readJavaFormatString(FloatingDecimal.java:1084)
        at java.lang.Double.parseDouble(Double.java:510)
        at java.text.DigitList.getDouble(DigitList.java:151)
        at java.text.DecimalFormat.parse(DecimalFormat.java:1303)
        at java.text.SimpleDateFormat.subParse(SimpleDateFormat.java:1918)
        at java.text.SimpleDateFormat.parse(SimpleDateFormat.java:1264)
        at java.text.DateFormat.parse(DateFormat.java:335)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.util.OutlookDate.parseDatePicker(OutlookDate.java:298)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.util.OutlookDate.isDatePickerDate(OutlookDate.java:334)
        at com.atlassian.jira.issue.fields.DueDateSystemField.validateParams(DueDateSystemField.java:103)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.issue.IssueCreationHelperBeanImpl.validateCreateIssueFields(IssueCreationHelperBeanImpl.java:74)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.action.issue.CreateIssueDetails.doValidation(CreateIssueDetails.java:71)
...
...
{noformat}

The problem seems to be related to the non-thread safety of the DateFormat class, as pointed out on the [Sun Forum's page|http://forums.sun.com/thread.jspa?threadID=497693&messageID=2906187]. It seems like an OutlookDate object has been used in a non-thread safe manner.
fields.summary: Non thread safe use of DateFormat

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15418].
  {panel}

1) Create a project ABC
2) Associate that project with a non-default issue type screen scheme
3) Create a new custom field, e.g. "Import Info", read-only text field
4) Associate "import info" with Default Screen

On my test jira, the customfield is 10170.  Change below as appropriate:

Run the following Jelly:

<JiraJelly xmlns:jira="jelly:com.atlassian.jira.jelly.enterprise.JiraTagLib">
<jira:CreateIssue project-key="ABC" reporter="burkholp" summary="test issue" assignee="-1" duplicateSummary="ignore" issueType="Task" priority="Normal" description="TEST">
<jira:AddCustomFieldValue id="customfield_10160" value="A working custom field" />
<jira:AddCustomFieldValue id="customfield_10170" value="A non-working custom field"/>
</jira:CreateIssue>
</JiraJelly>

The customfield_10170 silently disappears.  It's not only not displayed, but an XML dump of Jira doesn't have it either:

    <CustomFieldValue id="1169575" issue="27115" customfield="10160" stringvalue="A working custom field"/>

(and that's the only CF for issue #27115).

The Jelly run should either add the field value to the issue, or throw an error, but not silently discard it.
fields.summary: Jelly runner silently fails to add custom fields when there's no issue screen associated for that project/cf combination

fields.description:
In theory null should not be passed as an entity (issue or project) to the hasPermission methods. However, some bad code sometimes does this.

in this case, instead of allowing the code in hasPermission method to throw the real NullPointerException with a proper error message, the NullPointerException is dropped as another NullPointerException is generated in the finally block which is meant to generate method call timing statistics.

Need to ensure that line 126 in AbstractPermissionManager caters for null projectOrIssue.
fields.summary: NullPointerException in PermissionManager when null entity is passed

fields.description:
{quote}
Atlassian does not support JIRA downgrades. If you wish to downgrade the edition of your JIRA installation, please refer to the appropriate instructions below. Atlassian strongly recommends that you do not attempt to downgrade the version of your existing JIRA installation.

We recommend that you do not downgrade your edition of JIRA, (i.e. from JIRA Professional or JIRA Enterprise to JIRA Standard, or from JIRA Enterprise to JIRA Professional), as it is a non-trivial process that requires significant manual intervention.
{quote}

In some places we link directly to the child pages rather than to the main one. Also, people intend to perform a search for something like "downgrading from JIRA enterprise to professional" and never have opportunity to review the warning on the main page.

Finally, if the experience any issue with the downgrade they log a case in SAC where they get surprised by feedback about our policy.

The following pages should be updated:

http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/enterprise_to_pro.html
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/enterprise_to_standard.html
http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/pro_to_standard.html
fields.summary: Warning on the main downgrade page should be repeated on the child pages.

fields.description:
Currently if the user aborts a request during an attachment you get a nice big ugly exception:
{noformat}
008-08-10 14:59:34,917 http-j2ee.jira.atlassian.com%2F127.0.0.101-8080-Processor69 ERROR [jira.web.servlet.ViewAttachmentServlet] Error finding /13343/Comandos+do+DOS+(bat).pdf: null
ClientAbortException:  java.net.SocketException: Broken pipe
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.OutputBuffer.realWriteBytes(OutputBuffer.java:366)
        at org.apache.tomcat.util.buf.ByteChunk.flushBuffer(ByteChunk.java:432)
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.OutputBuffer.doFlush(OutputBuffer.java:314)
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.OutputBuffer.close(OutputBuffer.java:278)
        at org.apache.catalina.connector.CoyoteOutputStream.close(CoyoteOutputStream.java:104)
        at com.atlassian.jira.web.servlet.AbstractViewFileServlet.doGet(AbstractViewFileServlet.java:70)
        at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:690)
        at javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet.service(HttpServlet.java:803)
....
...
{noformat}

As we have done nothing wrong, we shouldn't spit out these big stack traces.  I actually don't see the harm in catching these exceptions and logging out as a WARN or even INFO.
fields.summary: Catch and quieten ClientAbortException in AbstractViewFileServlet

fields.description:
JIRA from time immemorial has always output

Unable to find 'webwork.multipart.saveDir' property setting

in its log.  Can we get rid of it as a warn level log error.

This [Google Search | http://www.google.com.au/search?q=Unable+to+find+'webwork.multipart.saveDir'+property+setting] shows how people get worried about.

I have also seen support cases where people are querying about it so it costs us somehting to have this harmless but annoying message in place

The offending class is JiraServletDispatcher

{code}
File tempdir = (File) config.getServletContext().getAttribute("javax.servlet.context.tempdir");
log.warn("Unable to find 'webwork.multipart.saveDir' property setting. Defaulting to javax.servlet.context.tempdir");
{code}                

It really should be a debug level warning.
fields.summary: Remove the Unable to find 'webwork.multipart.saveDir' property setting message.  It confuses people
Change logging level for trackback servlet

fields.description:
The quicksearch shortcut (which focuses the keyboard on the quicksearch field) is hard-coded to Q (the english shortcut) for the 3.13 beta

This means other languages' shortcut has no effect
fields.summary: quicksearch access key (shortcut key) broken in non-english languages

fields.description:
JIRA 3.13 beta 1 greets you with "Projekt Durchsuchen", "Vorgänge Finden", "Neuen Vorgang Erstellen".

Verbs must be written in lower case. So the correct spelling is "Projekt durchsuchen", "Vorgänge finden", "Neuen Vorgang erstellen".

(I was writhing in agony when I saw that navigation bar. It is so wrong. It hurts my eyes.)
fields.summary: incorrect uppercase german words

fields.description: On every comment, it says "added a comment -". For what purpose is this? It's annoying clutter.
fields.summary: From the Department of Redundancy department ... why say "added a comment -"

fields.description:
A "DataAccessException: Error occured while retrieving user with id '...'" bug was reported against Mylyn when retrieving an issue from a JIRA 3.12.3 repository that is assigned to a user that does not exist anymore. The repository has crowd integration enabled.

 236034: Synchronisation aborts, when entry is retrieved having a user which does not exist on server anymore
 https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=236034

Similar bugs have been filed here:

 http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-202
 http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-12360

Unfortunately the exception is thrown on the server side and there is no good way to recover on the client. Would it be possible to return a null user instead of throwing an exception in the case of a non-existant user?

I don't have a full stack trace since I don't have crowd and can not reproduce the scenario but I believe the SOAP call causing the exception is getIssue().
fields.summary: DataAccessException when getting issue that is assigned to deleted user

fields.description:
[See this KB entry | http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/KB/JSP-25164+-+ByteChunk+and+BodyContentImpl+caching+on+JIRA]

Setting tomcat.util.buf.StringCache.byte.enabled=true seems to enable caching of a class called ByteChunk.  This in turns leads to a growing cache of memory.

this is documented here

http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-6.0-doc/config/systemprops.html

Although this is a 6.0 document (and I cant find it in the 5.5 documentation) a search of the 5.5 code shows that it is used in 5.5

h2. What can we do?

We should probably look for this being set in the JIRA startup and then log a warning.  It may be possible to turn this off dynnamically but it appears that the system property is static referenced and hence we may not get a chance.

The Tomcat 5.5 class is called org.apache.tomcat.util.buf.StringCache
fields.summary: a new dangerous Tomcat caching property - tomcat.util.buf.StringCache.byte.enabled=true

fields.description:
Currently, if during the installation process _Install JIRA as Service_ is ticked off, the installer config the JIRA Start menu shortcut to be liked to _startup_bundled_jre.bat_

The installer doesn't install JIRA as the service by default (!). Despite that most of JIRA are used in the "server mode".

If for whatever reason "inexperienced" windows JIRA administrator install JIRA  in the "application" mode and accidentally closes the Tomcat terminal window, the user get surprised that it is impossible to access JIRA from the browser.
Moreover, he can't see the relationship between closing the terminal window and inaccessible JIRA.

The above automatically result in a new SAC case  that follow simple script:

USER: My JIRA is down !!!!! help me now !!!! I see in my browser "page cannot be displayed"
SUPPORT: Have you done any thing to JIRA... How do you start up your JIRA? ... and etc.
USER: From the Start menu;
SUPPORT: By any chance, have you closed the black window?
USER: Yes! Because I don't like black windows and I don't need it !!!
SUPPORT: Well ... If you don't like the black window, perhaps you should install JIRA as a service.
....

so, all together we have a few bounces before this "simple issue" is addressed.

Additionally, when the issue is finally resolved, the user faces other issue related to the installer and outlined in [JRA-15387|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-15387].

In summary, I strongly believe that:
# The installer should install the service by default. 
# The application mode should be optional. Additionally, it would still install the service but set it up to be started up manually and the Start menu item should be linked to _start_service.bat_. {{--Startup}} parameter passed to {{tomcat5.exe}}
# If there are users who might need to start up JIRA in the terminal window they should be able to do it  manually by calling _startup_bundled_jre.bat_. Perhaps some extra info in the doco page.
fields.summary: Installer should create the windows service and config it for manual start up for JIRA used in "application mode"

fields.description:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15387].
  {panel}

Background; windows admins often need "special" care and modification of the JIRA service either through the registry entries or passing some parameters to an exe file is often too much for them. 
For ref:
- http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/latest/runasservice.html#N1002C
- http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Setting+properties+and+options+on+startup
Often it is overwhelming, people get the change wrong (typos, wrong service etc) and the cases in SAC are being dragged on unnecessarily. 
Windows user are used to GUI rather than hacks in the registry or commands in the terminal. After all that is why they use Windows not Linux :D

I can recall some cases in SAC where I asked the users why the use WAR in Tomcat rather than the standalone and the answer was "Tomcat has Monitor"

The tool can be used of various things such as adding JVM options, increasing the memory, creating thread dumps; just to name three.

More over, the feature is already out there in any JIRA standalone and by providing access to it, we can greatly improve the user experience. 

!TomcatMonitor.png|thumbnail!

It is enabled by calling {{tomcat5w.exe}} with _MS_ parameter and the service name that you want to connect to. More on that at http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-5.5-doc/windows-service-howto.html

So for e.g. in JIRA the Monitor tool can be started up by executing the following:

"C:\Program Files\JIRA-Professional-3.12.3\bin\tomcat5w.exe" //MS//JIRA120608145928

The monitor can be quite easily configured to be started up on the OS start up by adding the config entry to the registry.
{noformat}
[HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run]
"JIRA Monitor"="\"C:\\Program Files\\JIRA-Professional-3.12.3\\bin\\tomcat5w.exe\" //MS//JIRA120608145928"
{noformat}
fields.summary: Enable Tomcat Monitor in JIRA on Windows

To replicate:

1. Select any filter, so the Issue Navigator is shown.
2. Select the "Manage" link.
3. Select the "Subcribe" link on any *other* filter (screenshot-1).

The screen that is shown (screenshot-2) will allow you to set the subscription for the selected filter, which may not be the filter that is shown on the left of the screen. This is very confusing. Would it be possible to fix this by changing the currently selected filter in the session when the user selects the "Subscribe" link?

fields.description:
The documentation for this portlet http://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/docs/v3.12.3/twodimfilterstats_portlet.html does not specify the custom fields that are supported.

A customer has changed their workflow to use this portlet with a numerical custom field. There is no documentation that this portlet does not support numerical fields, only these custom field types: 'Group picker', 'Multi select', 'User picker', 'Select list' and 'Version picker' custom field type.

The customer is midway into a project assuming numeric custom fields could be used.
fields.summary: Documentation on Two Dimentional Statistics Filter Portlet needs to specify suported custom fields

Group picker', 'Multi select', 'User picker', 'Select list' and 'Version picker' custom field type.

Watcher management is clunky and not obvious

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15380].
  {panel}

When posting a comment or making any other change to a bug, there's no immediate indication of who will be sent email as a result.

It's hard for ordinary users to even find out:
  * Watchers are a couple of clicks away
  * It's not obvious whether reporters, commenters, or other people listed directly on the bug page itself will receive comments
  * There can be people who receive email for every bug in a project because of notification schemes

A simple status list just below the comment field listing all the recipients would help alleviate this.
fields.summary: Tell users who notifications will be sent to before the action is performed

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-15374].
  {panel}

I'm looking at the very first Jira Setup screen. It'd be cool if all these fields were filled-in by default with some path that might make sense. If we know that certain operating systems like to store data in their own 'favorite places', then we could even default to them, but that's a bit more advanced/headache. We would just need to pick something semi-intelligent -- not / and not /tmp - etc.

http://localhost:8080/secure/Setup.jspa

Also, the backup path with the on/off switch for enabling/disabling backups is not consistent with the ability to add attachments or not. For attachments, if you put in a path, then presumably you've enabled attachments. This is not the case for backups, however. I can understand wanting to stress an explicity On/Off switch with backups, but in the end, I think these settings should be consitent.

So, maybe attachments have their own 'On/Off' radio button, and it is set to 'On' by default, and the path is pre-filled, and if you choose 'Off', then the path box goes grey, and the path disappears from the input box. I notice that the backups path input box gets disabled, as it should, when you choose to disable backups - so that is cool - I wonder if it is possible to grey it out to - change the background color of the now-disabled box to stress that it is disabled, as it is not completely obvious that it is disabled.

After all of this, the only thing I'll have to do for a new install is paste in my license key and click 'Next'.  :)
fields.summary: Would like default 'Index path', 'Attachments path', and 'Backups path' pre-configured and pre-filled in Jira Setup

As shown by the screenshot, rows on a sharable entity search results table are sometimes incorrectly offset one cell right. Additionally the renderer appears to miscalculate the available width of the cell and the contents of the last cell overrun the visible border of the table.

It seems likely that a browser bug is involved, but no reliable reproduction steps have been found.
fields.summary: Intermitted table layout bug for sharable entity results (FF2)

fields.description:
When a user browses to the Manage Dashboard or Manage Filter page then the following logic should be used to determine which tab to show (in order):
# If the user has clicked a particular tab, then show that one.
# If the user has been to this page previously in this session, then we remember which tab the user was last on.
In this case, we show that one again, unless it is empty (for Favourite or My).
(We remember separately for Filters and Dashboards)
# If the "Favourite" tab is non-empty, then show that one.
# If the "My" tab  is non-empty, then show that one.
# Finally, show the "Popular" tab.
fields.summary: Add smarts to choosing the default tab in Manage Dashboard and Manage Filter

fields.description: If you add the 2D Stats portlet to a dashboard, you can see that it adds a bigger gap above and below itself than other portlets.
fields.summary: The 2D Statistics Portlet does not align itself vertically correctly - it adds an extra 5 pixels at the top and bottom of itself.

fields.summary: Remove a link to another issue

fields.description:
When moving issues with bulk change, you are warned that versions are not retained from one project to the other:
"Issues not in the project Apogee Portal will not retain values for Affects Version/s"; 
"Issues not in the project Apogee Portal will not retain values for Fix Version/s".
(Besides, I think the Retain check box there is therefore obsolete).
But more importantly, you are not warned for custom fields which also use that version list (Version picker field).  The retain check box is available, so you assume these values will be retained.
But since it uses the same values as Affected version and Fix version, of course it is not retained and written with the value you selected (default Unknown).
I would expect the same warning as for Affected/Fix version.
The same is valid for Assignee/Reporter that is not a member of the new project. This field is filled in as Anonymous.  Understandable, but there was no similar warning as for Versions.

Consequence: after I did this Move, I had to correct all the Verified in Version values manually.
fields.summary: Bulk change, Move issues: Retaining does not work for a custom field with Version Picker
